description: A roll & move game for children in kindergarten, meant to educate them about the bad effects of bullying. Players roll a die and move their pawn. If they land on certain space they must draw a card. Players can choose whether to draw from the Friendship deck (moving them forward a few spaces) or the Bullying deck (moving them backwards a few spaces). The first player to reach space number 80 wins.

name: KR-spilið
description:
A trivia game about football (soccer) and especially the KR football club in Reykjavík, Iceland. Over 2000 questions included.

Players roll a die to move their pawn on a circular track around the board. They must answer questions according to which type of spot they land on. The first player to the finish line wins the game.

name: Experten Quiz Reiten
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of equestrian sport
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Horse racing: longest distance?
Western riding: dress regulations?
What is the meaning of 'hoofbeat'?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Experten Quiz Oper
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of opera
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Which opera of Verdi was played for the opening of the opera house at Cairo in 1869?
Which card game is played in Puccini's opera 'The Girl of the Golden West'?
content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Music, Party Game, Trivia

name: Experten Quiz Architektur
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of architecture
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Who built the Guggenheim museum in NYC?
Which is the highest church in Germany?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Trivia

name: Experten Quiz Wein
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of wine
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Which name is not used descibing the size of a bottle:
Balthasar, Marie-Jeanne, Melchior, Methusalem?
content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Trivia

name: Experten Quiz Fussball
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of soccer
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
volume of a standard soccer ball?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Experten Quiz Jagd
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of hunting
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
What is meant with 'Schwesternflinten'?
What is meant with 'kundige Person'?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Trivia

name: Claim to Fame Travel Edition
description:
To win Claim to Fame, you need to be the first team to move from start to finish by getting your team members to yell out five facts about celebrities and other famous people. Each round you have sixty seconds to deliver verbal hints, act out charades, draw clues – or all three – to aide teammates in guessing the facts listed on the back of your celebrity card.

Claim to Fame Travel Edition includes celebrity cards that can be used in the base game, while also being playable as a game on their own without the other components.

name: Master & Commander: Frigates
description:
“Frigates!" cried Nelson,"Were I to die this moment, want of frigates, would be found engraved on my heart" (Nelson said these words when he was chasing round the Mediterranean in search of the French expedition to Egypt)

Attached to a fleet, the frigates were the eyes and ears, ranging in line abreast over a immense expanse of sea while battleships kept steadily on line ahead, repeating signals and carrying dispatches.

Detached either singly or in small squadrons the frigates might be sent anywhere in the world to attack enemy commerce and protect their own, to hunt down privateers or pirates, or to take part in the conquest of yet another colony.

In the British Admiralty the Frigates were rated 5th rate, and small frigates 6th rate, the other small vessels used to support the operations of the frigates were classified as unrated, and they include a variety of ships from the larger corvettes and sloops of war to the small cutters and schooners. We include too, some 4th rates two deckers vessels, that, in some cases were used to execute and support frigate duties despite they were slow and cumbersome an many of them out-dated.

All this operations and engagements are covered by our rules Master & Commander Frigates. We have included 48 British, 48 Spanish, 48 French, 48 US, 40 Dutch & 24 Danish ships, including Two deckers, Frigates, Rasées, Sloops of War, Brigs of War, Schooners, & Cutters. The years covered with the ships are from the American War of Independence, French Revolutionary Wars, Napoleonic Wars, & 1812 War.

To play Frigates you need the Master & Commander Rules, Turning Templates, and Sailing Tables from Capitan Games. Along with these you will need the optional rule for Beating. All of these can be downloaded in pdf format (A4 paper size) from the Capitan Games website.

name: Stoked! Skateboarding Must Die
description: Collectible card game set in a future where skateboarding is illegal. The first two runs of the cards are called Vegalas and Socalia. The cards feature real art from Birdhouse skateboards and cartoon versions of two Birdhouse skateboarders. Each player creates a deck as in most collectable card games. You will play places to skate, money, equipment and people who will help you. There are also skateboard tricks that can be linked in sequence to earn "stoke" points. Earn 360 points and you win, if you drop to zero game over.

name: Flush royal
description:
The object of the game is to mark the most points by forming "hands" of poker.

Everyone draws 5 cards and in his turn, arises from one to five of his cards on the board, to complement the "hands" of poker, interconnected as crosswords.

At the end of the game the scoring begins.
Player scores 2 to 42 points for poker combinations:
2 points per pair to 42 points per Royal Flush.

name: El Emperador de Jade
description:
The Jade Emperor

In the Jade Emperor players to take the Chinese zodiac signs to play.

The purpose of to travel the game board with zodiac signs in order to become the first to bring the final square your chips on the board.

The game board boxes contain divert to other players boxes and if you find another sign of the zodiac enemy in the same square, occupying the box the player must start again from scratch.

The first player to wear their zodiac three chips tabs at the end of the course wins the game.


El Emperador de Jade es un juego de estrategia sobre un tablero que refleja un año lunar chino y sus correspondientes estaciones anuales.
He diseñado un sistema de movimiento que no depende de ningún dado para ello, y si los jugadores lo desean tampoco serán necesarios los dados para los eventos, pudiendo utilizar ciertas cartas como sustitutos, pero si además quieren jugar una partida más rápida en tiempo, pueden usar un sistema mixto que acelera la mecánica del mismo reduciendo el tiempo a la mitad.
El tablero es algo más grande que el de un ajedrez 12×10 y aunque pueda parecer que en un principio es un juego de recorrido, este juego tiene un alto grado de estrategia y planificación, de forma que los jugadores deberán tener en cuenta como juegan con sus fichas y los posibles movimientos que más les interese realizar.
Los eventos son muy simples pero con un alto grado de implicación en el juego y como interactúen con ellos puede suponer una ventaja tanto como una desventaja a la hora de mover sus fichas, pero que nadie crea que se puede quedar esperando a que llegue una mejor oportunidad, por que otros signos del zodiaco podrán capturarles y dar al traste con los planes del más oportunista.
Para el control de azar los jugadores pueden disponer de dados o de cartas y los recursos que deben obtener los jugadores son limitados, pero el sistema también atiende a los casos que se pudieran producir vacíos de elementos y los puede volver a retornar al juego, aunque ciertas fichas de los jugadores pueden ser retiradas del tablero de juego no es un juego por eliminación y desde el primero hasta el ultimo dispondrán de las mismas oportunidades.
Otro tema que me parece interesante destacar es el turno en el que jugaran los diferentes participantes, en este aspecto no es un juego lineal y excepto en la primera ronda, los jugadores moverán sus fichas por el orden descendente a la posición en el tablero, de esta forma los jugadores se alternan pudiendo mover diferentes veces en cada ronda de juego según tengan posicionadas sus fichas, de esta forma si hay muchos jugadores nadie se aburrirá esperando a que le toque su turno.
Por ultimo otro tema que me parece se debe destacar es el de los componentes, todo el juego completo incluido el tablero son tres hojas de A4, y en realidad con el tablero y la Rueda zodiacal el juego tendría la base mínima de componentes, con unas fichas de colores del parchís, un dado de ocho, y uno de seis podrías jugar sin tener que imprimir nada más.
No obstante he incluido el juego al completo, el juego básico son tres hojas, y una hoja más para las cartas, para quien desee imprimirlas, las realice en formato pequeño para imprimir en papel adhesivo y pegarlas en cartas de pequeño formato, baratas y fáciles de conseguir en “todo a 100″, todas las cartas entran en un A4.
Espero que disfrutéis jugando tanto como yo diseñándolo.
A imprimir y jugar un saludo.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Point to Point Movement, Variable Phase Order

name: Hexagone
description:
Object of the game is to be the first players to have toured the multicultural France (central hexagon) and have successfully responded to the ultimate question.

Each player rolls the dice to determine his home community (Africa, Asia, No Paper, North Africa, France, Europe)

In his turn, a player rolls the dice and moves his pawn as many spaces. If it lands on a space issue, it must draw a card question and answer it before the end of the hourglass, otherwise it returns to its original square. If it lands on a space event, he must draw an event card and follow the instructions.

After answering a final question of his community, the game is won.

name: Wandern -- oh, wandern
description:
Objective: be the first to reach the target (field 70)
- moving by turn -
‘Roll and Move’ game
move according die roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on cover inside
Equipment: board, 6 meeples (can be extended up to 8), 1 die

name: LGDN: La gym des neurones
description:
The gym neurons is a set of questions involving insight, memory or observation. The aim is to give the right answer as quickly as possible. The game takes place in three phases:

Round 1: This is the right answer to 8 MCQ (multiple choice) in the time allotted by the hourglass. Players who gave the correct answer earning units of "time" in the form of chips. At the end of the 8 questions, the player who accumulated the least amount of "time" is eliminated.

2nd round: The remaining players are faced with a 7 QCM and Memo matter where they are to observe an image for 15 seconds and then answer a question. The correct answers give points and avoid penalties. The two players with the most points qualify for the finals.

The Final: The two players have 2 minutes to answer six questions of pictorial logic. The player with the most correct answers wins, in case of equality, is one who has accumulated the most chips "time" wins.
categories: Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle, Real-time, Trivia

name: Attention à la Marche
description:
1000 funny questions on the daily life and habits of the French!

The game takes place in 3 rounds. The first round candidates submit questions, to keep his friends as close as possible to the correct answer. Candidates are then subjected to a second test: they must play as a team to the game "more or less" and restore their friend. Finally, comes the final round of the red carpet where you can multiply your winnings with each correct answer!

name: La carte aux trésors
description:
The game contains ten adventures taking place in ten "major regions" of France.

The first part takes place on three tracks, "Profession," "Objects" and "index", which are always based on the region visited. Young players have easier questions than adults, but all play on the same level of play

At the end of the game, and provided evidence previously gathered, players set off in search of the compass. They can continue to accumulate evidence by answering questions or taking the risk to travel to the city where the rose is in their opinion.

name: OPFOR Steel on Steel
description:
OPFOR Steel on Steel returns to the days of massed near-peer armies – but in contemporary times. The game pits the BLUFOR (U.S.) against OPFOR (World Class Opposing Forces).

In the game both players select appropriate combat and combat support units to capture key terrian. Each brigade area is then assigned a Mission Card for that battle sector. EAB (Echelons Above Brigade) units, from divisional units to air power, are drawn to give a hand of force multipliers. Combat and combat support cards are revealed to find initial strengths in each terrian sector. Mission cards are revealed to modify those strengths. Finally, EAB cards are played from the hand one card at a time in final attempts to win in each battle area.

The player who wins two of the three key terrian battle areas is the winner.

name: Doomed
description:
In Doomed you play a fallen angel who has sold its soul to Mephistopheles for a promise that was never repaid. Now you are exploring Hell to destroy the prince and take his throne.

You will face monsters, bosses, and Mephistopheles himself. In order to defeat monsters and escape events, you'll roll dice, with items, potions and skills boosting your chances of reaching Mephistopheles. Thankfully you're not alone when fighting against the boss as those are cooperative fights.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Knips-Tips
description:
Dexterity game, where the goal is to make a ring jump and catch the right symbols.

Each player bets the same number of fruits, chocolates, chips, tokes etc. Then a schema with 1X2 in 12 rows is filled out randomly, and each player takes turn trying to make the ring jump and hit the right symbol for the next row. You win by getting the most correct hits, or by hitting the 12 above the other symbols. The winner takes half the bets, and the rest is shared among the rest of the players, based on the number of correct hits.

The game can also be used to blind-guess next weeks football results.

name: The Game of Riverton, N.J.
description:
Objective: become wealthiest player -
- acting by turn -
This is a version of Monopoly put out in Riverton, New Jersey. It features businesses local to the area, such as Victorian Thymes, Parker's Flower Shop, Leedom's Texaco Service...
There are no hotels/houses, just bonuses for collecting groups, and has a unique "lottery" system ==> Lotso for gambling your money.
Game ends after agreed time or only one player left.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Higgs Boson
description:
The Higgs Boson, be the first to find it.
Higgs Boson, a board game where you control photons, electrons even neutrons and blast your way to victory.
Only one scientist can win, make sure it is you.

Players may move 1 unit each go, except when moving Electrons. A player may move 1 electron 2 zones or 2 electrons 1 zone during their turn. Neutrons move across the flat sides of zones, and may move as many zones a a player likes until it runs into another unit.

Each player begins with 3 photons, 1 for each colour. Photons may only land on zones of the same colour. Photons travel in straight lines and move across the points of zones. Photons travel like a wave so while they travel in a straight line from point to point, they only come into contact with the board on the appropriate coloured zones. Like Neutrons, Photons may not pass through a zone occupied by another unit. Your Scientist may only move 1 zone per turn.

All the units can move in any direction in keeping with their movement properties.

If you land on your another players unit you 'take' them, you move into the space and the 'taken' unit is removed from the board. If your Scientist is killed you are out of the game.

The Higgs Boson is hidden in the middle of the board. The first player to find it by landing their scientist on it is the winner.

name: Codon: The DNA Game
description: In Codon: The DNA Game, you are a student scientist competing against other scientists to determine the structure of five proteins involved in five common human diseases: cancer, AIDS, cystic fibrosis, muscular dystrophy, and diabetes. Each scientist player will roll the DNA Dice to identify the amino acids in these five human proteins. The scientist who identifies the most amino acids will earn the most points and win the game.

name: On the First Day of Christmas
description:
The 80-card deck contains cards ranked from 12 to 1 based on the "Twelve Days of Christmas" Christmas carol, along with two Wild Cards. There are twelve 12s, eleven 11s, and so forth, with a single card ranked 1. The lower the number, the better the rank.

Before starting, each player draws a card to determine their position. Lowest number is the King/Queen, up to the highest number being the Junior Townsperson. The Wild card counts as 13 for this.

The deck is dealt out to all players and the object is to get rid of your cards as fast as possible. The hand begins with one person playing one or more card to the center of the table. The cards played must all be of the same rank (Wild cards may be played with any other cards). Each player in turn must now either play the same number of cards of a better rank, or pass. Play continues around the table until everyone has passed; at that point, the cards are cleared and whoever played the last set of cards leads the next round. After everyone has gone out, the players are ranked. For example, the person who first got rid of all his cards becomes the new King/Queen. At the end of each round, points are tallied based on the new position. King/Queen is 5, Prince/Princess (second) is 3, Duke/Duchess (third) is 2 and all others are Junior Townspeople are 1 point. Players then change seat position to represent the new hierarchy and begin another round. Highest score at the end of 5 rounds wins.

Gameplay is like The Great Dalmuti, except that game has a finite end after 5 rounds, and maximum players are 6 instead of 8.

name: Piramika
description:
PiramiKa is a board game based chips in ancient Egyptian gods and culture.

At some point in the history of gaming chips Egyptians took shape and was born chess.

This game is an attempt to return the chips to a board where the chips are the Egyptian gods that depending on the nature of each god endow them with special powers.

The game flows out on a board where players can develop different strategies and should capture the god Ka / Ra to win the game.

But like in ancient Egypt, the Nile River has its importance random events creating different depending on the date provided by the board calendar, which is responsible for registering the course of days and nights of the week is up, which turn up the months of the year according to the ancient Egyptians saw, besides other event has been included as a force that is even above the gods who make up the game, this is Khepri the Egyptian scarab.

As in the game of chess mathematical possibilities are endless, but PiramiKa not a game of chess and each player can plan a strategy to capture the god Ra / Ka of his opponent in many different ways.

Battles are an important part of the game, various meetings with Khepri the beetle will have their importance if exceeded, each god may assert his power, but if he loses the game shall be removed and this battle can not be avoided, as to the battles between gods a balanced strategy can result in losing or winning the game.

On components of the game are easy to manufacture and this PnP version I included only black and white for anyone who wishes to try the game.

The game is complete and tested, with special care the balance between players and relation to the different components, a large development behind this game is based on the understanding the world who had the ancient Egyptians, as well as an equally important support in mathematics they used.

Definitely try to create a balanced game with a strong mathematical basis while the chance may frustrate the most brilliant strategic plans established by the players, so the perfect balance between them will win the player plus a proper strategic approach in as far as possible take into account the possibility that chance might hold both players during the course of the game.


PiramiKa es un juego de tablero que basa sus fichas en antiguos dioses egipcios y su cultura.

En algún momento de la historia las fichas de los juegos egipcios tomaron forma y nació el ajedrez.

Este juego es un intento por devolver las fichas a un tablero donde las fichas son dioses egipcios a los que dependiendo de la naturaleza de cada dios se les doto de poderes especiales.

El juego se trascurre en un tablero donde los jugadores podrán desarrollar diferentes estrategias y deberán capturar al dios Ka/Ra para ganar el juego.

Pero al igual que en el antiguo Egipto, el rió Nilo tendrá su importancia creando diferentes eventos aleatorios dependiendo de la fecha que proporciona el tablero calendario, que es el encargado de registrar el trascurso de días y noches de las que se componen las semanas, que a su vez componen los meses del año según los veían los antiguos egipcios, ademas otro evento ha sido incluido como una fuerza que esta incluso por encima de los dioses que componen el juego, este es Jepri el escarabajo egipcio.

Al igual que en el juego del ajedrez las posibilidades matemáticas son infinitas, pero PiramiKa no es un juego de ajedrez y cada jugador puede planear una estrategia para capturar al dios de Ra/Ka de su oponente de muy diferentes formas.

Las batallas son una parte importante del juego, los diferentes encuentros con Jepri el escarabajo tendrán su importancia si es superada, cada dios podrá hacer valer su poder, pero si pierde deberá ser retirado del juego y esta batalla no podrá ser evitada, en cuanto a la batallas entre dioses una equilibrada estrategia puede dar como resultado el perder o ganar la partida.

Sobre los componentes del juego son de una fácil fabricación y en este PnP solo incluí la versión en blanco y negro para quien lo desee pueda probar el juego.

El juego esta completo y comprobado, cuide especialmente el equilibrio entre jugadores y relación con los diferentes componentes, hay un gran desarrollo detrás de este juego que está basado en la forma de entender el mundo que tenían los antiguos egipcios, así como un no menos importante apoyo en las matemáticas que utilizaron.

En definitiva intente crear un juego equilibrado con una importante base matemática a la vez que el azar puede malograr los más brillantes planes estratégicos establecidos por los jugadores, de esta forma el perfecto equilibrio entre ambos darán la victoria al jugador que además de un planteamiento estratégico correcto, en medida de lo posible tenga en cuenta las posibilidades que el azar pueda deparar a ambos jugadores durante el trascurso de la partida.

name: Crusader States
description:
Crusader States is a non-collectible card game for 3-5 players. Each player represents one of the major European crusader factions as they attempt to carve out a kingdom during their march to the Holy Land.

Cards represent key nobles, money, cities, soldiers and titles as well as events and battles. By skillfully playing your hand you attempt to form a kingdom that is both powerful in votes and powerful enough to fend off the lurking Saracens as well as your fellow crusaders.

name: Buying Spree
description:
Objective: be the first player to reach the Check Out after collecting one grocery disc for each item on your shopping list
- moving/acting by turn -
spin & move according to the number along the trail; you may move forward or backwards, but in one direction only;
collect grocery discs, spread on the trail (only those, which are on your list);
meeting another player (ending on the same space) you may pick one disc from him/her;

name: Auf geht's mit der Rheinischen Post
description:
A promotional Game by a regional newspaper for cultural attractions in the Rheinland region in the West of Germany.

Players roll a die and move a pawn along a track through the region "discovering it" by drawing and reading cards when they land on certain spaces.

name: Kaiju Fight
description:
Published in Game Market 2004.

The game is composed of 2 rounds.
In the first round, players bids to get his monster, its 4 attacks, its 3 defenses, its 2 special abilities and its 1 weakness. Now, each player has his monster with 4 attacks and 3 defenses and 2 special abilities and 1 weakness.
In the second round, each player attack one of other monster in agility order.
The game ends when only one monster survive the second round.

name: Caleórn y la Maldición del Lobisome
description:
We are in northern Spain in the late ninth century. The mercenary camp led by Basurde has been cursed; his men are butchered by a dreadful beast. Thus, Basurde, his adopted son Gilem, and Sabba a mysterious and strange monster-buster woman decide to investigate these events and put an end to the killing.

They discover a Basurde’s old sorceress enemy behind all this. She’s well protected inside her cave, built with powerful magical defenses which can only be broken by placing three stellar rocks at its entrance.

Each player’s goal is finding a stellar rock and face together the sorceress in her own cave, the Den of Wolves. A series of tests and challenges will be required before the rocks are reachable. Meanwhile, the player who controls the sorceress will also control all the enemies and events happening to the adventurers in the game.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Admiral of the Black
description:
Admiral of the Black is set in the Golden Age of Piracy. It is both a board game and a deck building game. Players take the roles of pirate captains and compete against each other by raiding merchant ships for trade goods and treasure that earn them Victory Points. They also must visit friendly ports to trade goods, add new crew members, and purchase arms and equipment. These new crew members, arms, and equipment cards are added to their decks.

The board is a map of the Caribbean with a hexagonal grid. Players move on the edges of the hexes while the merchant ships move from one hex to the next. A player may engage a ship in battle when its ship is on a hex edge adjacent to a merchant ship. Once an enemy ship is defeated in naval combat the player may initiate boarding combat.

Both naval and boarding combat are resolved through the player's Naval Combat and Boarding Combat decks. An additional six-sided die is added to the combat score.

The game ends when the Admiral of the Black (the leader of the pirates) is defeated and a new Admiral of the Black is declared by the player with the most Victory Points.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Trading

name: Matchlocks on the Warpath
description:
Subtitled: Skirmish Rules for the Early Gunpowder Era

Mainly for recreating small conflicts during the settling of America. Also can be used to simulate actions in Europe, pirates and Colonial conflicts.

For skirmish combat between up to 80 figures per side. A figure represents one character. Each player command one or two units of 5-10 characters.

Units are activated randomly using cards, then the unit leader consumes Activation Points to make soldiers act.

A ring-bound booklet of 22 pages with a cardstock cheat sheet.
Eleven sample units and Optional rules are provided as Appendix.

name: Lezen &cetera
description:
A Rummy-like card game with World Literature as theme. Each card represents a famous book from the World Literature, including a (colored) theme, and a short description with highlighted keywords. Players try and lay combinations of cards based on the colored theme (beginners), the keywords in the description (intermediate), or self-defined connections between the books (advanced).

Designed by Dutch writer and journalist Pieter Steinz.

name: Fahrt ins All
description:
This east German game simulates the cosmonaut's training that supposedly boys were always dreaming about.
The first half of the game is a snakes and ladders part: Players roll dice and move ahead the strenuous training path. On some fields, they are allowed to move ahead fast because of "excellent performances", other field lets them fall behind for "insufficient performances". When a player reaches the 30th field of the track, his or her plastic cosmonaut is inserted into a plastic rocket and is ready for take-off. After rolling a six, the rocket is moved along a path to a distant planet, and the game turns into a basic roll and move game. After skipping a turn on the planet, players take off again and reach earth again on a different path. The first player to return home safely is the winner.

The game is free of political agitation and focusses on the hardships of the cosmonaut's training. It is remarkable that this ancient game (which has only two pages of rules anyway) contains a rule overview on the back side of the rule booklet.

name: Imps Vs Puppies: Hissy Fits
description:
The first expansion to the trick taking game of puppy smashing chaos, Hissy Fits introduces 8 new Imps and the dangerous new Ninja Kittens to the crate decks.

New character abilities run the gamut from resurrecting dead imps, stopping other abilities from triggering, even reversing the order of strength for the round. Once upon a time, not winning a round was at least a little safe but the new Ninja Kitten spring from their smashed crates and kill the weakest Imp in the round.

All the additions are specifically designed to make this game tougher and more strategic, obviously players experienced in Imps Vs Puppies need apply. This expansion requires the base game to be played.

name: Strange Salads
description: Party game. Each guest receives a question card. The game takes the form of a quiz where all the answers relate in some way to something used to maka a salad. The guest who gets most right, wins.

name: Travel Battlehits
description: Typical of this game in the public domain, each player deploys one’s own fleet of five ships on a ten-by-ten square grid that is hidden from the opponent. Because each ship consists of a series of pegs that are the same color rather than physical ship, units may be placed on the grid diagonally as well orthogonally. In turn, each player shoots at the other's grid by calling a location. The defender responds by "Hit!" when the call happens to be the location of a unit or "Miss!" when a unit is not located there. Each player tries to deduce where the enemy ships are and sink them. First to do so wins. Players use an erasable crayon to record calls on a second smaller grid.

name: Pot-Shot
description:
Shooting target game not without some humour.

Players take turns shooting at an array of three targets; a pheasant in flight, a duck wading and a gamekeeper reloading his gun. If you hit the pheasant you score 15 points; if you hit the duck you get 10 points, but if you hit the gamekeeper (oops!), you lose 5 points.

First to score a pre-set total of points, wins.

name: Robin Hood Shooting Game
description:
A shooting target game featuring famous images associated with the Outlaw of Sherwood Forest.

The target has four characters. Two mounted Normans and two unmounted knights. I think the mounted character in plain clothes so-to-speak is probably the dastardley Sheriff of Nottingham.

Each player takes turns and the one who has the most successes after a pre-agreed number of rounds, wins.

name: The New Game of Aerial Puff Ball
description:
A twist on the mechanics used in Blow Football games but this time a lot more abstract and aimed at adults (judging by the image on the box).

This is probably an original Edwardian Parlour Game. The box is placed in the middle of the table with the cup fixed upon the post in the centre. Each player takes a blower (8 included), and placing the coloured balls one by one in the end of it, endeavours to blow them into the box. Each player in turn puffs all the balls, and scores the numbers of the divisions into which they fall. A ball resting in the Cup counts as 25.

The game is won by the player who first scores 50 or 100, as may be agreed when starting.

name: Tiddly Hoop
description:
A tiddlywink variant that requires a lot of tiddle on your wink.

Between the player and the scoring board is a three-dimensional clown illustration. The clown is holding up a hoop. To score anything the player must launch a counter tiddlywink fashion, up through the hoop and then onto the board. I suggest this was quite difficult to accomplish first time.

At the back of the board there is a score board where you can record your successes. First to the end of the scoreboard track, wins

name: Desert Island Game
description:
Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game. The board track covers 'Setting Sail' and ends on the desert island and safety. Obey instructions if you land on special squares. First to arrive at the end of the track, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

name: Fairground Game
description:
Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game, taking ideas from Ludo in some places. Each player has four men and their designated start point. The board track covers various encounters with fairground attractions. When you land on one, you must follow the instructions. If you land on another player's piece, that piece is sent back to the start.

First to get all four pices home, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

name: Jungle Game
description:
Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game. The board track covers the Expedition Start and ends at the expedition end, where a boat awaits your arrival. Obey instructions if you land on special squares. First to arrive at the end of the track, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

name: Spot-A-Lott
description:
Game for children to play on long car journeys. The board is magnetic, especially important because the game is intended to be played in a moving car.

Cards provide the things to spot and you can score from 1 to 6 points depending on the rarity of the thing to spot. As you score points, you move your player marker along the track. The one who is furthest up the track, wins.

name: One Night Only
description: One Night Only is a game for 3 to 5 players who each take the role of a Band in their humble beginnings and guide them to the heights of Fame. Players choose actions to increase of Band's confidence so they will be able to play larger and larger gigs - thus gathering more and more Fame (and Money). Next they will bid Cash to hire a Bookie who will use his prestige to get the Bands gigs. Players can even play gigs together as Headliner and Opener. At the end of the game, whoever has the highest Fame, is the Winner!

name: The British Empire
description:
Patriotic card game, made when Britain actually had an Empire but one that was fading fast.

The objective is to gain certain cards to complete sets. The different feature as that the sets have a differing number of cards within them. For example, to collect Ireland cards, you will need 4 cards to complete the set. But to collect England & Wales cards, you would need 6 cards to complete the set.

When all the possible sets have been collected, the one with the most sets wins.

name: Oggle Boggle
description:
Very strange game and nothing to do with the more famous Boggle game.

Place the heads on a smooth surface and put an eye-ball in each socket, making sure that the pupils do not show. All players then place a fly disc on their cards in an agreed position, say, at the top of the head. Players then proceed to align the eyes on the fly by moving the card about In any direction or by rotating It. The first to achieve the alignment then decides where all players shall next place the fly. The eyes remain in the position achieved at the end of the first round. The player who is first 3 times is the winner.

name: The Handicap Race Game
description:
Tin-plate game. It consists of a spinner with eight unequal areas. Each area is assigned to a horse and the bigger the are allocated, the shorter the odds for that horse.

Players just place their bets and spin the spinner. After the result, pay the winners and take in the losing bets.

I suspect that it was assumed that you would use counters as the 'money' and the one with the most counters after an agreed number of races, wins.

I can see no reason why adults might play this by using real money instead of counters.

name: Leap-O
description:
Action game. Each player has three balls that must be loaded into a spring-like device, one at a time. If you press down on the device and then let go, the ball will fly out, hopefully towards the board. On the board are 9 squares, each square having a point value. Furthermore, each square has a fixed ring and the ball must stay within a ring to score. The scores range from 5 to 30 points.

First to reach a pre-agreed total score, wins.

name: Defenders of Faith
description:
Jesus Christ has promised us that he will be returning, and as a follower of Christ we know that this is true. But what about the people that don't know? Jesus gave us our great commission to go into all the corners of the world and share the gospel, and that is exactly what we will do.

Your character cards will be your friends, your family and your fellow church members, each with their own set of unique skills and encouragements. When a coal is separate from the fire, it grows cold. Keep great people around you and your faith will grow.

You will also have support, in the form of churches, bible studies, small groups and even education. These support cards will stay in play and give you greater opportunities to travel and spread out across the world. But the mission field starts right at home, will you witness to your neighbor or to a total stranger?

You may travel across the entire globe on mission trips. Some may be only for a single turn (think of it as a youth group trip to the Ukraine or Mexico) and some may take over the rest of the game (such as settling a family in another country, or becoming a pastor for a military branch overseas). Wherever you go, you will always have people to witness to.

The win condition. Sharing Christ's love is not a race, and cannot be kept track of via face down prizes or a life total. So we create a new card type, the Mission card. Therefore go into all of the world, and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them and and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. Each player will have at least one Mission card within their deck, and when you have met your requirements listed on the mission card, you can reveal it to your opponent. The first player to finish their mission does not automatically win however, as the game is not a race. Instead, each Mission has an assigned point value based on its difficulty, and when one player runs out of cards in their deck, whoever has more Mission points wins that game.

Don't think for a moment that lower point values are easy and high point values are hard, remember the woman who gave two coins? Her gifts to the Father were greater than those of the rich men.

name: Quizmo Money
description:
A bingo style game with two variants. In the first ruleset, the caller calls out an amount, and the players check their cards which show pictures of coins for a match. A row of four across, three down, four corners or entire card wins (winning pattern announced at the start of the game.

In the second ruleset, the game is the same but the cards and calling are different. Players have a card with coin amounts instead of pictures of coins. The caller calls out a description of a set of coins (i.e. "two dimes and one nickel").

AKA: Quizmo Money

name: Special Delivery: A Baby Shower Game
description:
Special Delivery is a new and unique baby shower and family board game for the purpose of entertaining baby shower guests and to play at home to reinforce to young children that a new baby is coming into the family. After the game is played with the kids, the months of the trimesters can be crossed off the board as the months pass so that children will get an idea of when the baby will arrive!

This project is a fast moving, hilarious and exciting game for baby showers and couples and family game nights. The game takes an unlimited amount of baby shower guests through delightful scenes of the 3 trimesters of pregnancy as players move their cute minature pink and blue milk bottle tokens up the game board -- from the 1st trimester when the father starts sweating and yanking his collar loose when the doctor tells him he's going to be a daddy, to the 2nd trimester where the now obviously pregnant wife is instructing the bewildered husband to repaint the nursery, and to the 3rd trimester where the anxious mom on a gurney nearly chokes the daddy as she clutches his tie on the way to the delivery room -- while teams take turns trying to draw baby-related words and phrases from the cards in the card box on pink and blue scratchpads. As their teammates successfully guess the word or phrase being drawn, they advance their milk bottle tokens up the gameboard to the Special Deivery space to "deliver their baby." Hilarious sketches and guesses encite non-stop laughter.

name: Astromino
description:
Astromino -- Dominoes of the Universe

This is a new twist on the age old theme of Domino games from times past. Astromino uses the universe, space travel as an overall game theme. The tiles have the form of the Kite and the Dart, original shapes developed by Sir Roger Penrose as a part of his tiling research projects in the 1970‘s. When “Dominized” these unique shapes open a new set of possibilities for Domino game design and play. Astromino Basic, Full and Advanced Sets are recommended for ages 8 through 101 years. We have play tested Astromino and to date it has done well with all age groups. This Kickstarter Project will be a mega play testing opportunity. The tiles can also be used as blocks or a puzzle just to form shapes and make patterns, it is one way of playing solitaire Astromino.

Astromino Game Sets

The Basic Astromino Game includes 60 tiles (30 Kites and 30 Darts) with sharp gray scale graphics. Basic game instructions are included.
The Full Astromino Game includes 100 tiles (50 Kites and 50 Darts) with four color graphics. Full game instructions are included with this set of tiles. Two playing surfaces for the more complex games, approximately 22” x 34” with game instructions make the Full set into an Advanced Game of Astromino.


Astromino Game Play Basics

To start the game “Big Bang” the tiles, i.e. shuffle or mix them face down on a large table top to form the “Galaxy”. Now choose a tile to determine who starts the game. The player with the highest double tile will be the starter. Once the starter is determined the other players return the tile to the Galaxy as the starter places his double to start the game.
Now each player will choose their own hand from the Galaxy, 5 Kites and 5 Darts. Each contestant plays one tile per turn from their hand of ten tiles, matching like numbers on the tiles, long edges to long edges and short to short. The basic game continues as a string of connected shapes the Moon and the Star take shape. These shapes Moon and Star must be formed using 5 Kites or 5 Darts, respectively. The shapes are assembled and connected, one to another as the game proceeds. The string of shapes undulates and forms the line of play, always a unique field of play. Like Domino games a typical hand in an Astromino game will last between 15 and 25 minutes.
Tiles may fit here or there and need to be turned and matched in your head as you choose your next move. Careful don’t make an “Anti-matter” move or if caught you will lose your turn! Strategy comes into play as you make plans for your next move to defeat your favorite opponent(s). Hide your tiles using the Player Tray.
If you are lucky maybe you can “Shoot the Moon”, it is a play where you complete any shape and clear your hand by playing two (2) or more tiles all at once. Astromino rules include many options so you can choose from them and play the game as you like it.


Game Options

There are six diferent games each one can incorporate these options to some degree. Play options include Rule of Seven, Blank is a wild to play, Add a Shape, Shoot the Moon, and scoring sevens or just scoring tile values with extra points for completing a shape.


Winning the Game

Although optional scoring rules are included, the main goal of the game is to use all the Astromino tiles in your hand. When you are down to your last Astromino tile yell “ASTEROID!” Fair warning to the opponents you are about to defeat. You win the hand when all your tiles are played. You win the game when you win two hands. Maybe you will be lucky enough to “Shoot the Moon” for the win.


Six Unique Games in one!

Basic Line of Play Game
Moons and Stars Game
Sun, Earth and Moon Game
Sumerian Sevens and Twelves Game
Freeform Penrose Tiling Game
Four-Stage-Star Game

name: Live It Up: A Game About Drugs and Consequences
description:
Live It Up: A Game About Drugs and Consequences is a fun family game which educates about the serious consequences of drug use while reinforcing the positive aspects of a drug-free life. The primary purpose of Live It Up is to be used as an educational tool, but it is an enjoyable game that can be played casually by adults and young people as well.

Live It Up is a useful visual, audio, and kinetic learning tool. Parents and Educators can play Live It Up with their preteens and teens, while Therapists also will find Live It Up useful for rehab patients.

Live It Up is played with five kinds of cards: Live, Activity, Arrest, Overdose, and Sober cards. The cards are laid out face down on the table. Each player chooses cards and stacks them until they receive a Live card, in which case their turn is up. If a player pulls an Arrest card, their stack of cards go into Jail, only to be redeemed by a player who pulls a Sober card. If a player pulls an Overdose, all their cards go to The Grave, never to be played again. Players can choose to redeem their Sober cards whenever on their turn they wish, but the longer they wait, the more they risk having their own cards sent to Jail or the Grave. The object of the game is to build the most fulfilling life, and the player with the greatest stack of Live, Activity, and/or Sober cards wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Seven Minutes in Heaven
description:
The object of this game is to move your pawn along "love tracks" and reach the finish square. Rolling a die determines how far along the "love track" you may move on your turn. In so doing, you win time to kiss the person of the opposite sex closest to your pawn. When you land on a square with a heart sign, cupid sign, male sign, or female sign, you draw a card with the matching sign and follow the instructions. The first person to complete all of their card-driven tasks and reach their finish square first, wins the game.

From the game box: "Seven Minutes in Heaven is an entertaining game that will liven any party. The object is to strategically race along love tracks and reach the finish squares. You will find the journey sensuously exciting, intellectually stimulating, and emotionally thrilling. This game is a unique "ice breaker", because the fun experienced along the love track makes everyone a winner."

name: Urgence
description:
The goal is to be the first to succeed three humanitarian missions in 3 different countries.
The board represents two circuits: an external circuit to collect the necessities of the mission, and an internal loop to achieve the mission.

In each round, the player rolls the dice and advance in the direction he wants and if his pawn lands on a square of an element it needs to collect, it takes that element, otherwise it says "I give" and can assign this element against a Solidarity card to the player who needs it for his own mission.

First player to succeed his/her three missions is the winner and is named the best chef.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Gods of Fantasy
description:
Introduction

"Gods of Fantasy" is a card game that puts you in control of fantasy creatures. You act like a God and you lead a tactical fight. Each player plays cards from their own hand. You can have Creatures, Items and Victory cards. All cards are drawn from a central draw pile. The game is simple enough that it can be learned and played in a short time, and the battles are different each time you play a new game. This is a game for 2-4 players and pairs. Experienced players should be able to finish one game in 50 minutes.

Object of the Game

To win, you must have more Victory points than other players.

Contents

When you open a game box, you'll find the deck of cards which contains 54 cards. Each deck represents the unique Creatures, Items and Victory cards. The cards are well-balanced and competitive straight out of the box. This guarantees that you will have a satisfyingly unique game experience every time.
Each game box contains:
54 card deck designed by professional artist, and a Manual in full color with rules and lots of examples of play.

Setting up the Game

This game can play:
2 - 4 players
2 vs. 2 (playing in pairs)

Playing the Game

Please for further instructions read the PDF manual.

Important

There is only one deck and that's it! You don't have to buy special cards to make better decks!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management

name: Tas-Mania
description:
The goal is to bring the most of cups of Nesquik at locations of its own pawns, in the area called "Safety Zone". Whoever has the most cups won.

Each player roll the dice in his turn and moves either his checkers or cups (yellow pins) on the ground the number shown on the die.
It is forbidden to cross a pond, a hedge, a pawn or a cup or, to be with two checkers on the same box. A pawn of the opponent can be eliminated when you're passing with one of his own pieces.

name: Publi Foly
description:
Player roll the dice and move on the board similar to Game of Goose and try to find advertising slogans as original as possible according to the boxes they landed.
Several boxes have known brand products containing bizarre ideas. You need to find the best slogan for this product.

examples:
"Terraillon Launches scales for two-seater twin brothers"
"Pepsodent Launches Toothpaste with polka dots."
etc.

name: Rock, Roadies and Roll
description:
Rock, Roadies and Roll is a game for 3 to 5 players where one must guide a band from the humble beginning playing in garages to the heights of fame! Bands are defined by four attributes which can be increased throughout the game: Confidence, Talent and Guitars, and Amps.

In Phase 1, players hire up to 3 Roadies and add these to their band of 3. They will place these 6 'workers' on action spaces such as: Drop off Demo tapes, Hang up Concert Posters, Record Album, Buy/Sell Gear, etc...

Phase 2 is a cash auction for Booking Agents which will lend their precious 'Leverage' to the band to get them gigs for the weekend.

Phase 3 is an auction using the Booking Agents' leverage to try to secure the best gigs for the weekend. Players can pick up gigs for Friday and/or Saturday.

Once the bidding is over, or all players have 2 gigs, players will 'play' their gigs. Add the band's confidence to 1D6 and compare to the difficulty of each gig to see if the Band bombed or blew the roof off! Increase your fame accordingly, get paid and cash in on royalties.

When the last gig card is drawn, complete that round. Whichever player has the most Fame, is the winner!

name: Verbiage
description: "An educational activity to teach and reinforce vocabulary skills" says the cover of the rulebook. There are four decks of cards, ranked by difficulty, that each contain three words, and their definitions. The basic game is for somebody to read all three words, and one of the definitions. The person or team whose turn it is has to identify which of the words goes with the definition read. A spinner decides what level of word (1 through 4) is used, and if the guess is correct, that team earns 100 to 400 points. First time to 5000 wins.

name: Precious Rum Barrels!
description:
Choose a rum barrel as your game piece. Highest roll goes first, then play continues clockwise. Roll the die move that many spaces.

Landing on sea snake spaces: take the sea snake, to cancel out all negative playing fields

Landing on Captain of the Ghost Pirate: roll a second time during your turn.

Landing on creepy skull: a player misses one turn.

End of Game: The player who reaches the Ghost Pirates' ship with the sea snake wins the game. If a player reaches the goal without the sea snake, he has to turn back to the blue field and continue from there.

components:
6 various colored barrels
1 Ghost Pirate
1 sea serpent
1 playing mat
1 die

name: The Game of Safety and Danger
description: Promotional game from Coca-Cola. The board represents the walk to home by any child. It follows the traditional formula of 'Goose' type games. Move along and if you land on a coloured space, obey the instructions. The first player to reach 'Home', wins.

name: Amuse Gueule
description:
Object of the game is to discover different characters through puzzles.

There are many prominent historical figures: politicians, entertainment, literature, art, real characters, mythical or imaginary, but always with a certain reputation.
Clue to four per person, are arranged on cards, in descending order of difficulty.

If player discovers a character he advances his pawn up to 4 squares on the board. The winner is the player who first reaches the fifth level of the pyramid (in the top easier).

name: Cheer Boys Cheer: Battles of 1861
description:
Scenario expansion for the Cheer Boys Cheer ruleset for the American Civil War. Four battles, all fought in 1861, with orders of battle, historical background, maps, rules and historical outcomes. Scenarios consist of:

Blackburn's Ford
Buck Hill
Greenbrier River
Belmont
categories: American Civil War, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures

name: Cheer Boys Cheer!: Battles of 1862
description:
Scenario expansion for the Cheer Boys Cheer ruleset for the American Civil War. Four battles, all fought in 1862, with orders of battle, historical background, maps, rules and historical outcomes. Scenarios consist of:

Mill Springs
Oak Grove
Parker's Crossroads
Richmond

name: Cheer Boys Cheer: Battles of 1864
description:
Scenario expansion for the Cheer Boys Cheer ruleset for the American Civil War. Four battles, all fought in 1864, with orders of battle, historical background, maps, rules and historical outcomes. Scenarios consist of:

Olustee
New Market
Mine Creek
Morton's Ford
categories: American Civil War, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Jeu des Sixties
description:
The Game of the Sixties is the game of questions, mimes, songs or drawings.

The box comes in the form of a jukebox: the outcome of the dice indicates the category with which we will play. Mostly, this is to answer questions, but sometimes you need to make small fun events. We can then find themselves dancing the twist, to mime or sketch a profile of a star.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Singing

name: La Mamma
description:
Cardgame based on Kemps

There are 4 different type of cards with Italian characters, and two cards for each player: Meals served and Bad food. You must collect 4 cards of the same family of Italians by changing the cards with opponents. You need to define a sign with Your partner and when this sign is done, your partner will then play the card "Meals served". But if opponent's team play the card "Bad food" before this they score a point instead Your team.
mechanics: Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Le petit jeu des Princesses et Chevaliers
description:
"Princesses and Knights" in English
Card game on the evolutionary theme of princesses and knights. By assembling the cards by 4, we can reconstruct various skits. The cards are laid on the table. Whoever gets the first card of a sketch can begin. The player may now find next card of this sketch etc. and finish the 4-cards sketch first to win the game.
Contents: 32 cards for eight sketches of four maps (castle courtyard of the castle, tower, dining room - the illustrations are duplicated, once with the characters, once without character), rules.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Medieval, Puzzle

name: Anglers Trivia Tournament
description:
"The Lure of This Game Will Hook You on the First Cast!"

Players take turns rolling, moving around the board, and answering trivia questions related to fishing. The winner gets a prize. The players, however, are instructed to determine what that prize will be before game play begins. (The game does not include any prizes itself.)

name: Call it!
description:
From the rules sheet: "Tension triumphs as two to six take turns tossing chips into the can... When you think the target number is reached, CALL IT! Dump out the chips and count 'em up - if you're below, you challenged too soon and you'll lose points - wait too long to challenge, and an opponent may take the round!

Object: To guess when the sum of the numbered chips in the can equals or exceeds the target number announced by the first player in the round"

contents: Can, 6 sets of chips numbered 1-10, score pad, pencil, rules.

name: Avant, Mon Enfants!
description:
Rules for a grand tactical Napoleonic miniatures game. Infantry are mounted three figures to 1"x2" base representing about 400 men. Calvary are mounted two figures to a 2"x2" stand representing about 300 men and horses. Artillery are mounted two men and a gun on a 2"x3" stand and represent about 200 men and 8 to 12 guns. Each turn represents one hour of game time.

On his a turn, a player moves any and all units up to their movement allowance, then declares attacks. An attack is resolved based on the combat factors of the units, the unit characteristics, and terrain.

The rulebook contains no information on how to design scenarios. Players sometimes recreated historical battles or historical what-ifs. Sometimes they played miscellaneous forces with no historical context. Many games were played as part of campaigns.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Springe (Two-Fisted Bluff)
description:
Springe (Two-Fisted Bluff) is a two-player game designed for play with a Shibumi set. It uses a 4×4-holed board, and balls in three colors (white, black, and red).

Aim: Make a full line (orthogonal or diagonal) of your color on a level, or get 9 of your balls on the board, or place the top piece of the pyramid, or (if both players run out of balls to play) have more of your balls in play than your opponent and more of yours than neutral balls.

Rules: The 4×4 board starts empty. Each player (White and Black) starts with his 16 balls, and 8 of the red neutral balls. Keep this supply of 24 balls hidden from your opponent at all times during the game. Use an opaque container (e.g. the Shibumi bag) to receive rejected balls over the course of the game. It should be able to hold all 48 balls, just in case. Never look in this reject bag during the game.
On your turn, hide any one or two balls total from your supply into your two hands. Each hand now has zero or one ball in it. Now present your closed fists to your opponent. Your opponent must sit still (no leaning and peeking), then touch one of your fists. Put the ball in this hand (if any) on the growing pyramid. Put the other hand (without looking!) into the reject bag, and release the ball (if any). Always do this, even if the other hand is empty, in order to keep your opponent guessing as to which balls you have left. If you run out of balls before your opponent, simply pass each turn until the game is over: You will still select which hand your opponent gets to play each turn.

name: Sprenge
description:
Sprenge is a three-player game designed for play with a Shibumi set. It uses a 4×4-holed board, and balls in three colors (white, black, and red).

Rules: The 4×4 board starts empty. The players, White, Black, and Red, take turns placing one ball of each of their opponent’s colors (e.g. White plays a black and a red) anywhere on the growing pyramid — they don’t need to be touching one another. The balls can be placed on board holes and/or on top of 2×2 platforms.

Aim: The player with the largest group of connected balls of her color when the pyramid is full wins. In case of a tie, the first player in turn order wins (i.e. White beats Black beats Red in a tie).

name: Mimanca
description:
The game consists of three tracks, laid out by tiles: An inner one that both players use and two outer ones, used by only one player each. At the outset of the game, each player places three pieces on each tile in the two lanes s/he can use.
Afterwards, the players take turns picking up all the pieces from one tile, then moving the pieces onward in the designated direction (the tracks are one-way and form a "round" track for each player, with the middle track being part of both players' tracks). At each tile they pass, they have to drop one piece. In the middle, they can choose which color to drop (if they have both colors in their hand), but when they reach the end of the middle track, the pieces are split up and continue their path in the different outer tracks.
If a tile on the outer tracks ever contains more than six pieces, that tile is removed together with all the pieces on it.
During the game, there are scorings at partially random moments. Each player counts the number of pieces on his or her outer track and gets points accordingly.
The game ends when one player has less than three tiles in his or her outer track. Then a final scoring is done, with the other player scoring double. The player with most points wins.

name: Greek Guardians
description:
[GreekGuardians.com]
Theme:
Greece of yesterday was a different place than it is today. The age of Ancient Greece was frought with peril, sacrifice and prayer. To get anything done, people would pray to the gods for favor. To complicate matters, the right prayer had to reach the right deity in order to have any chance at success. It was very confusing and complicated life. To simplify this vast set of choices a Greek everyman or everywoman would face, I have chosen two paths that you and your opponents must set your sights towards. Order and Chaos, both are neutral, they are not bad or good in the classical sense, but rather a point of view. By the end of the first players turn, each player must align with Order or Chaos and build their strategies and play their cards towards that means.

Goal:
Each player draws cards that move players towards your final goal of 21 culture points. Each action, each king, queen, god, monster, philosopher, literally each card can either add or subtract culture points, cause mayhem, deny abilities, outright kill foes, or otherwise meddle towards your cause or to take an opponent away from their cause, for your chosen faction (Order or Chaos). There is one initial turn to set up and identify which faction, Chaos or Order, you will be gaining points towards and then there are 4 turns, one per season: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter. If a player does not reach 21 culture points, at the final play of Winter, the player with the highest amount of culture points WINS!

Game-Play:
Players will determine who goes first and will draw (and play) cards in the correct slots (Gods, Titans, Stars, etc.) and each card will have passive and active effects that resolve at the end of each player's turn. There is a (normal sheet of paper size) game board that shows where different cards "live" Passive effects will usually be "Add one culture point towards either Order or Chaos" (depending on the Card's Alignment). Active effects (or action cards) will require using action points (each player gets 5 action points per turn; the game has 4 turns total, so each play and card management is very important) that can alter the landscape of the game and change fates FAST.

Unique Feature (Stacking):
Say a certain God card is played (let's say Zeus) and he is Chaos aligned. And say there is a chaos aligned star already in its slot and another chaos aligned Titan in her slot. There is a bonus, or stacking, effect of having a bunch of "like-minded" cards, so this combination of three cards (each say producing one chaos token for this turn, 1+1+1=3) there would be a +2 chaos bonus. So if the player can navigate the correct stacking of "like-minded" or similarly aligned cards, there are bonus effects that can speed up your plan (OR slow down opponents).
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Pattern Building

name: The Air Ship Game
description:
This game was published in 1904, and predates the Game of the North Pole which were both published by McLoughlin Bros.

The object is to be the first player to win a race with his "new air ship." The first player to reach or pass the balloon in the sky wins.

name: Race to Kyoto 1946
description:
Operational level wargame for fictional invasion to Kansai region in Japan at final stage of WW2. The game is inspired by the Race to Tokyo. However, this game is not race by two Allied Armies. Standardly one player control the US Army and another player control the Japanese Army.

The game play is repeat alternately movement and combat. The rule mostly same with Race to Tokyo.

The U.S. purpose is threatening the Kyoto, to lure out the Japanese Tokyo garrison.
The Japanese purpose is to have depleted the US units, to defense the Kansai region.
The actual winner determined by the control of the important city by U.S. Army and loss of U.S. units.

The game counters is not die-cut.

name: Limbo Party
description:
UNRELEASED GAME



Note that all details for this game are preliminary. If you have information about this game, you are invited to edit this section or submit corrections.




The animals are ready to dance, with the elephant wearing its grass skirt and ready to sway as the music swells. Dice drive the dancing in Limbo Party, and as the animals circle the limbo tree, they'll need to watch for the snake that winds its way around the tree. Ladders and vines can keep the animals safe if you know how to use them!

name: Sound Bites
description:
Trivia game that tests people's hearing rather than brain-power.

A CD provides the sounds as players compete to recognise audio clips or sound bites. Played in teams, everybody takes part at the same time, recalling classic lines from the movies, deciding who said that in quotes, guessing the year from the news headlines, solving sound effects, identifying catch phrases and much more.

The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Electronic, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music, Party Game, Trivia

name: Snoopy Dodgem Game
description:
The board has a clear central area and around the edge are 16 'slots'. Four Peanuts characters have four slots each. The characters are Charlie Brown, Woodstock, Linus and Lucy. Each player is assigned one of the characters.

Snoopy is in his Super Snoopy Dodgem Car which is friction driven. Rev him up and let him go in the middle of the board. The wheels are designed so that the car will chunter back and forth and eventually it should go into one of the slots, awarding that player points. Points are recorded on a score chart. First to complete their line in the chart, wins.

Contents
1 Playing Board
1 Score Board
1 tin plate Snoopy Dodgem Car
4 Coloured Scoring Pegs
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: Which Way to the Lodge... or I Would Have Been Here Sooner But...
description:
Which Way to the Lodge is a fast moving, fun moving after ski game for 2 to 6 players... drinking, loving and laughing!

Players roll dice to move around the board. If a player lands on a on a question card space another player draws a card and asks the question on the card. If the answer is correct the player moves ahead 3 spaces. If the answer is incorrect the player moves back 3 spaces. If a player lands on a Snow Bunny space the player must draw a card and perform the feat on the card. Some of the feats involve drinking. The winner is the first player to reach the lodge.

name: Colorado Cannabis Craze
description:
The Colorado Cannabis Craze, a 'friendly' competition to obtain the finest quality cannabis from the four corners of Colorado and return it to Denver for sale in their shop.
A group of daring individuals will attempt this cutthroat competition to become the next Colorado Cannabis Czar. This will be no easy task! Even though medicinal marijuana is legal, the Colorado Highway Patrol (CHP), the DEA, state and local fuzz do not practice under that same opinion. Get busted and you'll spend time at the preeson in beautiful Canon City. Fly into DIA and travel to the 8 Colorado Cannabis Cities all across Colorado trying to find your old grow buddies from back in the day.

Travel different highways with pros and cons to each, visit 'turn towns' from long ago and war with other players. All have the risk of the CHP, but also test your JUJU, take chances with 'WTF?' encounters and try to Flee buy cities with your cannabis purchase in strains like Bubblegum Skunk or Colorado Kindbud. Tempt your luck with the Cripple Creek Cashout or race back to the Colorado Cannabis Connection in Denver and sell your stash to get your million and get to DIA... Get busted by Homeland Security or meet up with the hip and helpful Hilljacks in this fun and entertaining game of strategy, luck and SAFETY!!

Winning The Game:
First player reaching DIA with all 8 Cannabis City Chips and $1,000,000 is the winner...
The New Colorado Cannabis Czar!!!
Up to 6 Players with 6 ways to play!
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Fitting & Proper
description:
Fitting & Proper is a puzzle game, one in a small line published by Springbok. There are 36 plastic pegs which are randomly placed in an 8x8 grid of holes, and 16 L-shaped plastic pieces with holes in various places into which the pegs fit.

If played as a solitaire puzzle, the object is to fit all 16 pieces on the grid. In the two-player version, the players divide the pieces equally and try to be the last to be able to place a piece.

name: Scheherazade y la Lámpara Maravillosa
description:
Scheherazade and the Wonderful Lamp is a cooperative-narrative game in which players create an amazing story using cards that show concepts or narrative elements of the fairy tales themselves.

Players must work together to tell an amazing story cooperative, incorporating ideas from other players on their own, so that will be spinning a nice adventure. On each turn, the active player Scheherazade, and as a storyteller create or continue an amazing story using the elements of his cards, trying to steer the argument towards a happy ending.

The goal of the game is that players have fun and tell a good story. Players will win if they can tell different stories entirely successful four (one of each color).

name: The Game of Lilith
description:
Baby Lilith ventured forth into the world. Now she needs to get back home.

In this game you roll custom dice to obtain different symbols. These symbols are then used to move along paths on the game boards, which will appear as the players advance. In the middle of eacht board, you have the possibility to win cards that will provide you with a bonus symbol.

The goal of the game is to be the first player to reach the center of the final board.

This is a PnP game I created as a gift for the birth of my daughter Lilith.

name: RotVar!
description:
RotVar! is a board game where two or more players challenge each other directly on the battlefield.
Play as the brave Humans or the noble Arverians, the keepers of the forest.
The game consists in a series of turns where the two factions alternating between quest and battles to the death.
Fight battles that involve dozens of friends or play face to face with your enemy!
Complete missions to earn gold, which is useful to buy all that you need to crush the enemy forces:
potions, weapons, armor, spells and skills.
Earn fame, useful to recruiting new characters to make your party more complete and destructive.

RotVar! does not have the usual races, The territory introduces new creatures and monsters.

In the basic version, you'll find the tokens of Humans, of the Arverians and the monsters;
The respective sheets with the parameters;
The cards of the weapons, armor, spells and skills;
The customizable board of the battles;
The map of the world;
The rules;
The manual of the battles.

Three different modes:
Skirmish -> 15-45 min
Adventure -> 3-4 hours
Campaign -> 8-12 hours

name: Matchmake
description:
An abstract game for two or three players. Each player starts with 14 pieces arranged in two diagonal lines on a 13x13 board. On their turn each player rolls a die and moves one of their pieces orthogonally the corresponding number of spaces. Enemy pieces may be captured by replacement.

The object is to get as many pieces as possible onto certain designated goal squares. Each player has separate goal squares.
The game ends when all of one player's surviving pieces are on that player's goal squares, but the winner is determined by counting scores: one point for each piece on a goal square, plus one point for each captured enemy, minus one point for each piece not on a goal square.

Published in the book The KnowHow Book of Action Games.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hop Over
description:
Abstract strategy game for two players. Each players starts with twelve pawns in one corner of a 13x13 board and must get them "home" to the opposite corner.

On their turn a player rolls the die and moves one pawn the corresponding number of spaces in a straight line. A roll of 6 allows a pawn to jump over another friendly pawn. Two or three pieces may occupy the same square: in this case they may be jumped over with a roll of 5 or 4.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: "Brownie" Kick-In Top
description:
The board consists of a wooden circular dish Around the board are 12 numbers (from 1 to 12). All the balls are placed into the centre of the dish. Players take turns to spin the top and the top will make the balls fly around the board and, hopefully, one or more to stop in the indentations before the numbers.

Here are the actual rules:
The complete game consists of one metal bowl, one wood top, one colored wood marble and four white wood marbles.
OBJECT OF THE GAME:—Place all marbles in center of bowl and spin the top. which will kick the marbles into the numbered holes at the outer edge of bowl.
THE COUNT:—The holes are numbered from one to twelve, the colored marble counts double and the white marbles count single.
EXAMPLE:—If colored marble is in number 10 and white marbles in numbers 5-3-7 and 9 you have 20+5+3+7+9=44.
Any number may play at one time.
The player spinning the highest total, wins.
Any marbles remaining in center of bowl after top stops spinning, do not count. You may play the game by:—
Leaving all balls remain where they stop.
Throwing balls from small numbers and try to get higher numbers.
The highest total for each spin.
The highest total for five or ten spins.
The player spinning 100-200-300400 or 500 first wins the game.
MANUFACTURED BY
M. H. MILLER COMPANY JEANNETTE, PA.

name: Pushee
description:
Pushee is a finite and drawless race game for two players.

Play is on a 5x5 board, with both players pushing in opposite directions. Each player has 5 pieces, numbered 1 through 5, which all start on their back row. It is suggested that the initial arrangement of pieces on the back row be selected randomly.

Players take turns pushing pieces forwards. A 'push' consists of pushing a piece one space forward, onto the space immediately ahead or the ones onto the left or right of that. A player may either push just the 1 piece forwards, or push forwards a piece and pull back the piece one size less onto any of the three squares behind it. For example, they may push forwards the 4 and pull back the 3, but not push forwards the 4 and pull back the 2, or just push forwards the 4 without pulling anything back.

A piece may not be pushed or pulled onto an occupied square, but a piece may push back a smaller opposing piece onto any of the three squares behind it. The person doing the pushing decides which square the opposing piece gets pushed onto.
